Summary: This measure amends the definition of “psychiatric residential treatment facility,” adding among other conditions that all facility residents meet the certification of need for service requirements identified under 42 C.F.R Part 441, Subpart D.
Sponsor: Rep. Frances Cavenaugh (R), Sen. Melissa Thomas Irvin (R), Rep. Jeremy Woodbridge (R)

Summary: This measure establishes a task force to study and make recommendations concerning certificates of need, including the following matters: instituting a price increase cap tied to the cost growth benchmark for consolidations; guaranteed local representation of communities on hospital boards; changes to the Office of Health Strategy's state-wide health plan to include an analysis of services and the impact of such services on equity and underserved populations; setting standards for measuring quality as a result of consolidation; and enacting higher penalties for noncompliance; among others.

This measure prohibits certificates of need from consideration unless certain documentation requirements have been met. The measure also gives authority to the commissioner of social services to place conditions on any decision approving or modifying a request for a certificate of need.

This measure modifies the state certificate of need (CON) program to require additional notice of transactions in the community; include support for resourcing experts to evaluate transactions for impact; subject provisions of agreed settlements to enforcement action for violations; and lower the state of mind requirement for violations from “willful” to “negligence” with a penalty of up to $1000 per day of violation. In exchange the state agreed to limit the time for reviewing applications, to exempt certain imaging equipment from CON review, and to issue determinations of CON within thirty days. These provisions are effective October 1, 2023. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.
Sponsor: Rep. Robyn Porter (D), Rep. Eleni Kavros DeGraw (D), Rep. Tammy Nuccio (R)

Summary: This measure exempts birth centers enrolled as a Connecticut Medical Assistance Program provider from the state’s CON requirements until June 30, 2028. The bill also requires the OHS executive director, in consultation with the DPH commissioner and within available appropriations, to study whether this CON exemption for birth centers should be extended. These provisions are effective October 1, 2023.
Sponsor: Rep. Robyn A. Porter (D), Rep. Trenee McGee (D)

Summary: This measure includes a provision that updates notice requirements for intermediate care facilities for individuals with intellectual disabilities under the certificate of need process, such as by requiring facility closure notices to go to the Office of the Developmental Services Ombudsperson rather than the Office of the Long-Term Care Ombudsman, and requiring the ombudsperson’s office to hold informational sessions related to these closures.

This measure allows parties involved in the transfer of ownership of a hospital requiring a certificate of need (CON) in which the hospital has filed for bankruptcy protection to apply for an emergency certificate of need. Requires the unit evaluating the emergency CON application to consider the effect the hospital’s bankruptcy could have on patients and the communities served.
Sponsor: Speaker of the House Matthew Ritter (D), Sen. Martin M. Looney (D), House Majority Leader Jason Rojas (D), Rep. Tom Delnicki (R)

Summary: This measure provided hospitals and health care service providers with a valid certificate of need that expired within 30 days prior to the declaration of a public health emergency a waiver from the need to renew the certificate of need until 60 days after the end of the public health emergency. This measure was passed on both an emergency and temporary basis -- The emergency legislation expired on 10/19/2021 and the temporary legislation expired on 5/5/2022.

This measure exempts certain health care services, entities, and equipment replacement from certificate of need and creates a registration system for certain health care entities no longer requiring a certificate of need.
Sponsor: Hon. Christina Henderson (I), Hon. Janeese George (D), Hon. Anita Bonds (D), Hon. Charles Allen (D)

Summary: This measure amends the certificate of need law to remove the capital expenditure threshold for projects or new institutional health services subject to review. The bill revises timelines for submission of a letter of intent by applicants, and revises timelines and processes for the Department of Community Health's review of applications. The bill also revises appeal processes for the Certificate of Need Appeal Panel after a decision has been issued. The bill revises and expands exemptions from certificate of need review. The bill includes a provision imposing a monetary penalty for noncompliance with prior notice and approval requirements. In addition, the Department of Community Health, with the Office of Legislative Counsel, is directed to review the certificate of need program and submit recommendations to the General Assembly by December 1, 2024.
Sponsor: Rep. Butch Parrish (R), Rep. Jon Burns (R)

Summary: This measure, among other provisions, exempts the conversion of a critical access hospital or general hospital to a rural emergency hospital from certificate of need requirements. The bill also exempts a change of a rural emergency hospital in licensure, organizational structure, or type of institutional health facility from certificate of need requirements. These provisions are effective March 28, 2023 and July 1, 2023.
Sponsor: Rep. Craig Johnson (R), Sen. Jeff Reichman (R)

Summary: This measure amends the definition of “ambulatory surgical center” under the certificate of need law and other statutes. The bill exempts cosmetic, reconstructive, or plastic surgery services provided in an ambulatory surgical center from certificate of need requirements.
Sponsor: Senate Committee on Health and Human Services

Summary: This measure includes a provision that would allow a previously licensed psychiatric medical institution for children (PMIC) that has the capacity to provide up to an additional four intermediate care beds for persons with an intellectual disability to increase their licensed capacity to include the additional beds without further certificate of need review including by the health facilities council. As of 2/21/2024, this measure has been amended to revise provisions unrelated to the certificate of need provision.
Sponsor: House Committee on Health and Human Services

Summary: This measure relates to boards, commissions, committees, councils, and other state government entities. The bill includes a provision that directs the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), in consultation with the Department of Inspections, Appeals, and Licensing (DIAL), and with the assistance of other interested parties, to conduct a study on the effectiveness of the current certificate of need process. HHS is directed to submit a report on its findings and recommendations to the governor and general assembly by December 31, 2025.

This measure removes birth centers from the meaning of institutional health facility, which would allow health care providers to create, relocate, expand, or offer new services in birth centers without the need to obtain a certificate of need.
Sponsor: House Committee on Health and Human Services

Summary: This measure requires the Department of Public Health to execute written inter-agency agreements with the Department of Human Services and Department on Aging to affect an increase in the determination of need scores for applicants for institutional and home and community-based long-term care.
Sponsor: Rep. Greg Harris (D)/Sen. Patrick Joyce (D), Rep. Robyn Gabel (D)

Summary: This measure requires health care facilities that are parties to certain covered transactions to provide 60-day advance notice to the attorney general. Transactions include mergers, acquisitions, or contracting affiliations between two or more health care facilities or provider organizations not previously under common ownership or contract affiliation. Failure to provide notice is subject to a $500 per day penalty for each day the party is in violation. That attorney general may investigate the transactions and may apply for a temporary restraining order or an injunction if the attorney general has reason to believe the facility is engaging in the transaction without complying with the notice requirement. There are no minimum dollar thresholds for reporting under the bill. Filings made under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act satisfy the notice requirement. These provisions are effective January 1, 2024.
Sponsor: Rep. Jennifer Gong-Gershowitz (D), Sen. Ann Gillespie (D)

Summary: This measure amends the Illinois Act on the Aging. In a provision requiring the Department on Aging to increase the effectiveness of the program, it removes a requirement that the Department ensure the determination of need tool is accurate in determining program participants' level of need.
Sponsor: Rep. Bob Morgan (D) / Sen. Mattie Hunter (D)

Summary: This measure allows a hospital that owns an ambulance service that is exempt from a certificate of need to provide transport services from another health facility to its hospital is authorized by the ambulance service provider with jurisdiction in the territory in which the other health facility is located. The measure also details certain outpatient categories of care that are exempt from certificates of need and licensure, including primary care centers, special health clinics, rural health clinics, and off-campus, hospital-acquired physician practices. If a city or county government has conducted a public hearing for the purpose of demonstrating that an imperative need exists to provide emergency ambulance transport services within its jurisdictional boundaries, it shall not be required to obtain a certificate of need for the city or county. The Legislative Research Commission shall establish the Emergency Medical Services Task Force to study the provision of emergency medical services in the state, the duties of the task force including a review of the need, or lack thereof, for the certificate of need process for ambulance services.

This measure defines "PACE" as programs of all-inclusive care for the elderly and "PACE service provider" as an organization that provides services for the elderly according to agreements between the provider, CMS and the Kentucky Department for Medicaid Services. PACE service providers are exempt from obtaining a health facility license or certificate of need to provide PACE services. As of 3/8/2024, this measure has been amended to exempt PACE service providers from obtaining a health facility license to provide PACE services.

This measure establishes that certain trauma centers that partner with a university to establish a medical residency program are entitled to the university hospital reimbursement rate for any residency program services. The bill includes a provision that requires that, before acquiring or constructing an acute care hospital, the University of Kentucky, the University of Louisville, or a medical system or college or school of medicine affiliate, must obtain the approval of the General Assembly. Such approval is required in addition to any certificate of need requirements.
This measure amends the Cabinet for Health and Family Services criteria to issue, deny, or revoke a certificate of need.
Sponsor: Rep. Jason Howell (R), Rep. Donald Douglas (R)

Summary: This measure prohibits the Kentucky Board of Emergency Medical Services from requiring an ambulance service from applying for licensure, within a specified time period, and requires submitting application progress reports after receiving a certificate of need. Ambulance services issued a certificate of need on or after July 14, 2022 can apply for licensure Board of Emergency Medical Services without obtaining a new certificate of need.

This measure requires certain health care providers to be subject to facility need review to determine the need for a new or additional facility, provider, program, service, or bed. The measure requires the Department of Health to establish a facility need review process for nursing facilities consistent with regulations for licensure and for Title XIX of the Social Security Act. The rules and regulations shall include but not be limited to: criteria for review of nursing facility beds to determine if there is a need for additional beds, specific duties of the department to review proposals for new facilities, appropriate methodology for the collection of data necessary for administration of the program, procedures to grant and revoke approvals, and establishment of application fees.

This measure establishes an assisted living residences commission to study assisted living residences and recommend policies to ensure assisted living residences adequately meet the health and safety needs of residents. As part of its work, the commission shall examine and make recommendations regarding regulatory procedures for opening, closing or changing ownership of a residence, including determination of need processes and clustering of facilities.
Sponsor: Rep. Tom Stanley (D), Rep. Kate Lipper-Garabedian (D), Rep. Lindsay Sabadosa (D) / Sen. Pat Jehlen (D)

Summary: This measure creates exceptions to the certificate of need requirement to include continuing care and continuing care at home agreements.
This measure, effective April 20, 2023, eliminates the state’s Certificate of Public Advantage (COPA) law.
This measure exempts positron emission tomography (PET) scanner services from certificate of need regulations.
Sponsor: Rep. Like Meerman (R) / Sen. Winnie Brinks (D)

Summary: This measure requires the department of health to assess fees and other assessments for health facility and agency licenses and certificates of need on an annual basis. The base fee schedule for facilities and projects of varying capital expenditure are detailed.

This measure restricts the establishment of a new hospital and any erection, building, alteration, reconstruction, modernization, improvement, extension, lease, or other acquisition by or on behalf of a hospital that increases the bed capacity of the hospital, relocates hospital beds from one physical facility or site to another, or otherwise results in an increase or redistribution of hospital beds within the state. The measure explicitly details which projects, modifications, and construction the restriction does not apply to.
Sponsor: Rep. Heather Edelson (D), Rep. Tony Albright (R)

Summary: This measure includes transaction review by the attorney general if the transaction is a large transaction. Transactions are specifically defined and involve a range of entities, and transactions that are anti-competitive are presumptively prohibited. The attorney general has the authority to unwind anti-competitive transactions. Notice must be provided for small and large transactions as defined under the legislation. Large transactions require the submission of additional detailed financial information to the commissioner of public health and the attorney general, including information filed with the federal government. Non-profit entities face additional reporting requirements. Minnesota specifically authorizes the use of APCD data to “conduct analyses of the impact of health care transactions on health care costs, market consolidation, and quality,” permits the use of data submitted to conduct aggregate analyses of the impact of transactions with respect to those same factors, and requires the commissioner of health to report periodically on the impact of transactions. The legislation also charges the commissioner of health with studying and developing recommendations on the regulation of conversions, mergers, transfers of assets of domiciled HMOs. These provisions are effective May 26, 2023 or January 1, 2024.
Sponsor: Rep. Robert Bierman (D), Rep. Tina Liebling (D), Rep, Zack Stephenson (D)

Summary: The measure prohibits certain activities without obtaining the required certificate of need, including: the construction, development, or establishment of a new health care facility; the relocation of a health care facility or major medical equipment unless that relocation does not involve a capital expenditure and is within 5,280 feet from the main entrance of the health care facility; any change in the existing bed complement of a health care facility; relocating one or more health services from one physical facility to another unless the relocation does not involve a capital expenditure and is to a facility within 5,280 feet from the main entrance of the facility; and changes in ownership of any health care facility in which a notice of intent has not been filed. The measure details under which circumstances a certificate of need may be granted.

This measure allows private hospitals, whether in a rural or nonrural area, to negotiate and enter into cooperative agreements, subject to receipt of a certificate of public advantage that is approved by the state department of health, effective March 30, 2023.
Sponsor: Sen. Joey Fillingane (R), Sen. Jenifer B. Branning (R), Sen. David Jordan (D)

Summary: This measure creates the State Board of Health, which may formulate the policy of the State Department of Health. The Department of Health's duties include the ability to extend and renew expired certificates of need, and to charge a fee for reviewing applications. As of 4/4/2024, this measure has been amended to revise provisions unrelated to the certificate of need provision.

This measure establishes no prohibitions or restrictions on participation in the Medicaid program for the person(s) receiving the certificate of need authorized under this measure or for beds converted pursuant to the authority of the certificate of need that would not apply to any other psychiatric residential treatment facility. Establishes certificate of need exception under certain circumstances for a crossover provider. Establishes a date for a certificate of need be issued to a certain entity in a specific county with a certain amount of beds.
Sponsor: Sen. Hob Bryan (D), Sen. Joseph Thomas (D), Sen. Derrick T Simmons (D), Sen. Bradford Blackmon (D)

Summary: This measure revises certificate-of-need requirements to include only long-term care facilities and services.
This measure amends legislation regarding the submission of certification of need letters of intent to the department of public health and human services.

This measure increases monetary value thresholds for requiring a certificate of need (CON) for diagnostic centers, major medical equipment, and new institutional health services. Each threshold shall be adjusted using the Medical Care Index component of the Consumer Price Index published by the U.S. Department of Labor for the 12-month period preceding the previous September 1. Additionally, a CON issued for the construction of a health service facility expires if the holder of the CON fails to initiate construction of the project authorized by the CON within the specified time frame.

This measure, effective March 27, 2023, removes psychiatric beds and facilities, chemical dependency treatment beds and facilities, Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment services for children under age 21 receiving care from home health agencies, and the first $3 million worth of replacement equipment in any health facility from certificate of need review. Effective 2 and 3 years after the first Healthcare Access and Stabilization Program payment is made, respectively, the bill also exempts ambulatory surgical centers located in a county with a population larger than 125,000 as well as MRI machines located in a county with a population larger than 125,000 from CON review.
Sponsor: Rep. Donny Lambeth (R), Rep. Donna McDowell White (R), Rep. Michael H. Wray (D), and Rep. Chris Humphrey (R)

Summary: This measure includes a provision to amend the Nebraska Health Care Certificate of Need Act to exempt rehabilitation beds and acute care beds from certificate of need requirements. As of 3/4/2024, this measure has been amended to revise provisions unrelated to the certificate of need provision.

This measure reduces the time lag between determination of need and actual occupancy thereof, to expedite construction, acquisition, or improvement of mental hygiene facilities for the care, maintenance, and treatment of individuals with developmental disabilities.

This measure requires entities to provide a 30-day pre-closing notice of closing of a material transactions valued at $25 million or more to the department of health and the attorney general’s office, so the transaction can be made public for input. This provision is effective ninety days after May 3, 2023. The legislation also requires 30-day public notice for general hospitals converting to rural emergency hopsitals to allow for a community forum on the impact of proposed inpatient bed closure and input on the process. This provision is effective sixty days after May 3, 2023. The department of health has the authority to issue rules governing documentation requirements and the notice requirements. Note: This is a larger bill that contains several provisions. Other provisions are included in the appropriate tab.

This measure makes temporary changes regarding certificates of need (CON); the changes apply to any CON granted between March 9, 2020 and June 18, 2021. The bill requires the Director of Health to grant a 24 month extension to CON holders to obligate capital expenditures and commence construction for a proposed project, and stipluates that the transfer of a CON prior to completion of the activity for which the certificate was granted does not void the CON.
Sponsor: Rep. Jean Schmidt (R), Rep. Sedrick Denson (D)

Summary: This measure requires any entity desiring to establish a new psychiatric or chemical dependency service or acquire, lease, or expand an existing service to make an application to the State Department of Health for a certificate of need. The bill details exemptions from the certificate of need program for certain health care providers and facilities.
Sponsor: Rep. Jeff Boatman (R), Sen. Chuck Hall (R)

Summary: This measure exempts a certificate of need review for any addition, deletion, modification, or construction of current or future state veterans home nursing facilities.
Sponsor: Sen. Brenda Stanley (R), Sen. Tommy Hardin (R)

Summary: This measure would repeal sections of the certificate of need law that are related to psychiatric and chemical dependency facilities. As of 3/4/2024, this measure has been amended to remove the effective date of November 1st, 2024, and establish an emergency. As of 4/30/2024, this measure has been amended to add to the list of repealed sections under the Psychiatric and Chemical Dependency Facility Certificate of Need Act.
Sponsor: Rep. Jeff Boatman (R), Sen. Julie Daniels (R)

Summary: This measure removes the requirement under the University Hospitals Authority Act to obtain a certificate of need.

This measure amends the certificate of need law, to require the Department of Health to annually convene a meeting of long-term care nursing to receive input regarding the Department's conduct of surveys, with the goal of promoting cooperation and communication between long-term care nursing facilities and the department. Information provided to or obtained by the Department under these provisions shall not be accessible under the state Right-to-Know law unless it is unrelated to long-term care facility performance, is false, or is independently corroborated.

This measure requires any person engaged in the conversion of a for-profit or not-for-profit corporation as the acquiror or acquiree involving the establishment, maintenance, or operation of a hospital to receive prior approval from both the department of attorney general and the department of health. The measure extends the timeline of approval or disapproval of conversion projects from 120 to 180 days of the application being accepted by the departments, and requires any hospital seeking conversion to apply additional information in their application, including: staffing levels, pension plans, and impacts for affected communities before and after conversion.

This measure modifies the state certificate of need (CON) program to eliminate CON requirements for certain health care facilities. Nursing homes are required to obtain a CON for changes including: construction or establishment of a new nursing home, changes to beds, capital expenditures exceeding a prescribed amount, capital expenditures associated with the addition or substantial expansion of certain health services, offering of a new health service, and acquisition of medical equipment resulting in costs exceeding the prescribed expenditure threshold. The Medical University of South Carolina is required to apply for a CON or licensure for acquisitions of hospital facilities. In addition, a CON will be required for the construction or other establishment of a hospital and a change in the existing bed complement of a hospital until January 1, 2027. The bill also establishes a CON study committee to examine the effect of the repeal of the CON program on the quality and quantity of access to health care in rural areas of the state. CON exemptions are amended for the relocation of a hospital under certain conditions, acquisition of a hospital by another person or health care facility, and crisis stabilization unit facilities. In addition, the bill amends considerations for project review criteria, adjusts the timeline of the CON application process, shortens certain time frames of CON administrative and judicial proceedings, and eliminates the role of the court of appeals. These provisions are effective May 2023.
Sponsor: Sen. Wes Climer (R), Sen. Penry Gustafson (R), Sen, Josh Kimbrell (R)

Summary: This measure exempts acute hospital care at home programs and services delivered by a licensed acute care hospital from certificate of need requirements. This measure also revises exemptions for continuing care retirement communities.
Sponsor: Sen. Tom Davis (R) et al. / Rep. Marvin Smith (R) et al.

Summary: This measure creates a health services and development agency that has jurisdiction and powers related to the certificate of need program and develops criteria and standards to guide the agency when issuing certificates of need. The measure increases, from 15 to 30 days, the period in which a party or any member of the health services and development agency may file notice to request the agency review an action of the executive director related to certificate of need.
Sponsor: Sen. Shane Reeves (R) / Rep. Clark Boyd (R)

Summary: This measure continues the requirement that a temporary healthcare staffing agency presently doing business in the state must provide notice to the health facilities commission identifying its business entity and any controlling person by December 31 of each year, instead of ending December 31, 2023. As of 4/17/2024, SB 2022 has been amended to include a provision that establishes that fees and civil penalties authorized by the certificate of need program, including those currently held in reserve, may be used to defray expenses incurred in the operation of the health facilities commission, rather than expenses incurred specifically from the administration of the certificate of need program. The bill removes the requirement that the health facilities commission adjust prescribed certificate of need fees to provide that revenues from fees do not exceed necessary and required expenditures.
Sponsor: Rep. Esther Helton-Haynes (R) et al. / Sen. Shane Reeves (R)

Summary: This measure directs the State Health Commissioner to accept and review applications and issue a certificate of public need for a new 90-bed nursing home facility, provided that such facility is located on the property of the former Central Virginia Training Center in Amherst County as of July 1, 2023.
This measure requires the Board of Health to promulgate regulations expanding the expedited application and review process for certificates of public need to numerous additional project types.

This measure requires the State Health Commissioner direct the State Health Services Plan Task Force to develop recommendations for establishing an expedited application and review process for projects which a certificate of public need is required that meet certain criteria.

This measure establishes that CON shall not be required if a medical care facility decides to use on average 10 swing beds per day. Requires the State Commissioner of Health collect swing beds data annually from critical access hospitals and make available to the public.

This measure directs the State Health Services Plan Task Force to develop recommendations for establishing an expedited application and review process for a certificate of public need in a medical desert.
Sponsor: Del. Wendell Walker (R). Del. Rodney Willett (D)

Summary: This measure amends and reenacts codes dictating which medical care facilities and projects are required to have a certificate of need. Outlines actions in which a medical care facility does not have to receive a certificate of need. Establishes an expedited certificate of public need application and review process for specific projects. Establishes exemptions from the requirement of a certification of public need under certain conditions.
This measure allows critical access hospitals to utilize an average of up to 10 swing beds per day, calculated over the hospital's fiscal year, without obtaining a certificate of public need.

This measure allows the Green Mountain Care Board to waive or permit variances, through March 31, 2023, from state laws, guidance, and standards with respect to certificates of need to prioritize and maximize direct patient care and safeguard the stability of health care providers responsive to the Covid-19 pandemic.

This measure establishes the Office of the Healthcare Advocate shall have the right to receive copies of all materials related to the certificate of need application review, and may ask questions and submit comments to the Green Mountain Board regarding certificate of need applications. This measure includes other provisions not related to certificate of need.
Sponsor: Rep. Mari Cordes (D), Rep. Daisy Berbeco (D), Rep. Allen Demar (R), Rep. Francis McFaun (R)

Summary: This measure increases the monetary thresholds triggering a certificate of need requirement, and exempts certain activities from certificate of need for those health care services and health care facility projects that are contract awards from the State.
Sponsor: Rep. Mari Cordes (D), Rep. Angela Arsenault (D), Rep. James Harrison (R), Rep. Michael Marcotte (R)

Summary: This measure extends certificate-of-need (CON) exemptions relating to psychiatric facilities and equipment until June 30, 2023. The department shall suspend the CON requirement for a hospital that changes the use of licensed beds to increase the number of beds to provide psychiatric services, including involuntary treatment services. A CON exemption granted under this bill will be valid for two years. Additionally, the bill extends exemptions from CON requirements for the construction, development, or establishment of a psychiatric hospital that will have no more than 16 beds and provide treatment to adults on 90- or 180-day involuntary commitment orders. The bill also states that psychiatric hospitals are exempt from CON requirements for the one-time addition of up to thirty new psychiatric beds. Lastly, an entity seeking to construct, develop, or establish a psychiatric hospital is exempt from certificate-of-need requirements if the proposed psychiatric hospital will have no more than 16 beds and dedicate a portion of the beds to providing treatment to adults on 90- or 180-day involuntary commitment orders. The psychiatric hospital may also provide treatment to adults on a 72-hour detention or 14-day involuntary commitment order.

This measure allows for an exemption from certificate of need requirements for a kidney disease center to exceed its authorized number of dialysis stations during certain temporary emergency situations, effective July 23, 2023.
This measure amends the certificate of need law, exempting the construction or establishment of psychiatric hospitals and the addition of psychiatric beds from certificate of need requirements.
This measure amends existing law, exempting elective percutaneous coronary intervention performed in certain hospitals owned or operate by a state entity from certificate of need requirements.
Sponsor: Majority Caucus Vice Chair Chipalo Street (D), Rep. Nicole Macri (D), Rep. Joe Schmick (R), Rep. Lisa Parshley (D)

Summary: This measure transfers jurisdiction over appeals of decisions of the Health Care Authority in certificate of need reviews from the Workers’ Compensation Office of Administrative Law Judges and Circuit Court of Kanawha County to the Intermediate Court of Appeals.

This measure exempts hospitals performing hospital-based services, birthing centers, and certain physician office practices seeking to acquire and utilize one magnetic resonance imaging scanner from certificate of need requirements, effective March 10, 2023.
This measure authorizes the Department of Health to promulgate a legislative rule filed in the state register, authorized under the rulemaking authority of the certificate of need law.

This measure amends existing law that prohibits the issuance of a certificate of need to an opioid treatment program. This measure establishes that an opioid treatment program that is an approved clinical trial for the study of office-based methadone versus buprenorphine to address retention in medication for opioid use disorder treatment may be developed for the limited purposes of and timeframe for the trial. This exemption only permits one program to participate once.
Sponsor: Sen. Craig Blair (R), Sen. Mike Woelfel (D) / Del. Roger Hanshaw (R), Del. Sean Hornbuckle (D)

Summary: This measure restricts the Department of Health to approving certificate of need alterations or additions of health care facilities for the purpose of healthcare and life safety compliance determinations only. Repeals bed expansion limitations for certain nursing care facilities and hospitals, and requires a report from the Department of Health to a committee on the status of construction of nursing care facilities with certain other information.
Sponsor: Rep. Rob Geringer (R), Rep. Martha Lawley (R), Rep. Chip Neiman (R), Sen. Christopher Rothfuss (D)
